content: apiraino and I were wondering in https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/245100-t-compiler.2Fwg-prioritization.2Falerts/topic/I-prioritize.20.2380303.20VecDeque's.20Hash.3A.3Ahash.20implementation.20is.E2.80.A6 if T-libs was using the I-nominated and I-needs-decision labels. I don't know anything about the team's workflow and meetings, it would be great if someone could clarify that to me. Thanks in advance :big_smile:

@Léo Lanteri Thauvin I-nominated issues are to be discussed in a meeting, because they'd be stuck otherwise. I-needs-decision issues need a decision, but that doesn't necessarily need to happen in a meeting. For those we still have the hope that a conclusion can be reached on the issue/PR itself, probably with some input/discussion from libs team members.

I-needs-decision issues do appear in our triage meeting agenda though, but we discuss I-nominated issues first. I-needs-decision issues are only discussed in the meetings if there's time left.
thanks for clarifying :thumbs_up:
If things are stuck on I-needs-decision, it might be good to have the libs team pinged on it, or add I-nominated to make sure it gets the attention it needs.
(For reference, the issue in question is #80303, where the libs team was pinged too)
Thanks. Nominated it for the next meeting. Seems important :)

if there's time left.

and there's never time left :sweat_smile:

The differences in team protocols here is interesting to observe. T-compiler currently puts I-needs-decision stuff earlier in agenda than I-nominated stuff. Historically we had a hard time getting through all the I-nominated stuff and so putting it early would mean that nothing else got addressed. So eventually the I-nominated list was moved to the back. More recently we’ve been better about trying to get through it.
That sounds like something we might want to try do consistently too

(Even more recently I’ve been musing about randomzing the order of the agenda sections, to avoid an overall trend of “these topics are always dominating and are always handled, to the detriment of other topics/agenda items”)
